## Simulated data

* total number of locations (*N*): $20, 40, 60, 80, 100, 120$
* type of spatial relations:
    * random
    * two more or less separable regions
    * central and periphery
* proportion of variation in the explored variable (*p*): $0.1, 0.2, \dots 0.5$
* amount of clusters (*k*): $0.1\times N, 0.2\times N, \dots 0.9\times N$
* percantage of observations taken from each cluster (*r*): $0.1, 0.2, \dots 0.9$

From  those values we could derive a number of sampled locations (n):

$$n = \frac{N\times r}{k}$$
